children: A 54-year-old woman is hospitalized with a painful skin lesion involving the breasts, as
shown
. She was started on warfarin 2 days ago for atrial fibrillation.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?′

The most likely diagnosis is protein C deficiency or resistance. Protein C is a vitamin K–dependent protein that degrades activated factors V and VIII and has an anticoagulant effect. Many persons with protein C deficiency will experience a thrombotic event or pregnancy morbidity before 50 years of age and have a strong family history of thrombosis. The half-life of protein C is shorter than many of the other vitamin K–dependent proteins. When warfarin is initiated in patients with protein C deficiency, warfarin-induced thrombotic skin necrosis can result from rapid depletion of protein C with a subsequent transient hypercoagulable state following the loss of its anticoagulant effect.

objective.__html: Diagnose protein C deficiency manifesting as warfarin-induced skin necrosis.

children: A 67-year-old woman is evaluated for anemia and hypercalcemia.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
This patient most likely has multiple myeloma. Increased serum proteins associated with multiple myeloma will cause rouleaux formation, or stacking of the erythrocytes, as
shown
. This “stacked-coin” appearance (
arrow

) of the erythrocytes can be seen in any condition associated with increased plasma proteins, including polyclonal or monoclonal gammopathies. The presence of anemia, hypercalcemia, and rouleaux formation is highly suggestive of multiple myeloma. Red cell agglutination may occur with cold agglutinin disease, but hypercalcemia is not a feature of this disease.

objective.__html: Diagnose rouleaux formation and recognize its association with multiple myeloma.

children: A 60-year-old woman is evaluated after a leukocyte count of 55,000/µL (55 × 10
/L) was found incidentally on a routine complete blood count.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). In CML, peripheral blood neutrophilia along with immature myeloid forms, such as myelocytes and metamyelocytes, are seen. This smear
shows
myelocytes (
red arrows
), band forms (
white arrows
), and mature polymorphonuclear neutrophils (
green arrows
). CML is a clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder characterized by translocation of the long arm of chromosomes 9 and 22 [t(9;22), Philadelphia chromosome] leading to a
BCR-ABL

fusion gene. This gene codes for an abnormal activated tyrosine kinase that promotes dysregulated cell proliferation. At diagnosis, patients with CML can be asymptomatic, with elevated neutrophil counts found on routine laboratory studies; or, they can have symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, abdominal fullness (splenomegaly), and bleeding.
An 18-year-old woman is discovered to have splenomegaly during a college sport preparticipation examination. She is asymptomatic. Her father has chronic asymptomatic anemia.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is hereditary spherocytosis. Spherocytes may be seen in hereditary spherocytosis and warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia.
Spherocytes
red arrow
) are characterized by erythrocytes with a spherical shape and lack of central pallor. The larger and lighter pinks cells are reticulocytes (
blue arrow
). The family history of anemia and the presence of splenomegaly are most compatible with hereditary spherocytosis.
A 49-year-old man is admitted to the ICU with meningococcal sepsis.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely hematologic diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. Examples of this disorder include thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, hemolytic uremic syndrome, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is confirmed by erythrocyte fragments
seen
on the peripheral blood smear that appear as schistocytes (irregularly shaped and jagged fragments) (
blue arrows
) and helmet cells (scooped-out erythrocytes that resemble a helmet or bucket) (
red arrow
). Recognition of these findings is essential, because they are associated with life-threatening disorders.
A 23-year-old man is evaluated for anemia, abdominal pain, and arthralgia. He recently renovated an old house, which included scraping and repainting.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is lead intoxication. The slide
shows
an erythrocyte with basophilic stippling characterized by the presence of blue granules in the cytoplasm (
arrow

). The blue granules are ribosomal precipitates. Basophilic stippling is associated with megaloblastic anemias (such as cobalamin deficiency), thalassemia, sickle cell anemia, sideroblastic anemia, alcohol overuse, and lead poisoning.

Lead toxicity can be the result of exposure to lead paint occupationally or in the home. Those at increased risk include construction workers and do-it-yourself home renovators working in older, lead-painted homes.
An 80-year-old woman is evaluated for anemia. She was recently diagnosed with end-stage kidney disease. She had a splenectomy 50 years ago following a motor vehicle accident.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's peripheral blood smear findings?
The most likely cause of this patient's peripheral blood smear findings is uremia. Echinocytes are erythrocytes with a relatively small number of
spicules
of uniform size and distribution that project from the cell surface (
black arrows

). They appear contracted and dense on stained peripheral blood smears. Echinocytes are most characteristically associated with uremia and liver disease, but may also be an artifact of preparing peripheral blood smears. Echinocytes are often confused with acanthocytes, but the projections of echinocytes are smaller, more uniform, and more uniformly distributed than those of acanthocytes.

objective.__html: Diagnose echinocytosis on a peripheral blood smear and recognize its association with uremia.

children: A 22-year-old man is evaluated for profound pancytopenia.
Bone marrow biopsy findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is aplastic anemia. The biopsy specimen shows profound hypocellularity. Fat and marrow stroma are the major components present, and there is no evidence of malignant cells or fibrosis, as would be seen with acute myelogenous leukemia or myelofibrosis. These bone marrow biopsy findings are consistent with a diagnosis of aplastic anemia. Aplastic anemia is characterized by diminished or absent hematopoietic precursors in the bone marrow, most frequently resulting from injury to the pluripotent stem cell. Such injury may occur secondary to drugs, radiation, infection, or immune disorders or may be idiopathic. The most common peripheral blood pattern seen in aplastic anemia is pancytopenia, with the simultaneous presence of neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, and anemia.

objective.__html: Diagnose aplastic anemia on bone marrow biopsy.

children: A patient with right lower extremity swelling is evaluated for possible deep venous thrombosis (DVT). Ultrasonography is performed with the probe just below the inguinal ligament in the transverse plane.
(Note that there is no sound for this
video
Which of the following is seen in this study?

The patient's ultrasound shows normal compression of the common femoral vein. Normally, in the absence of a clot, the anterior and posterior walls of the vein will touch when gentle pressure with the probe is applied, as demonstrated here. On the left side of the
video
, the common femoral artery (
white arrow
) can be seen pulsating just at the level of bifurcation, and the position of the greater saphenous vein (
red arrow

) on the right indicates that the collapsing structure is the common femoral vein. Normal compression suggests patency of the femoral vein and the absence of deep venous thrombosis (DVT). Compared with formal venous ultrasonography, which examines the entire lower extremity venous system, a point-of-care study for DVT typically images three sites: the common femoral vein (
yellow arrow

); the junction of the common femoral, femoral, and deep femoral veins; and the popliteal vein at the level of the knee. Results of a point-of-care study for DVT should be considered indeterminate if the intended vessels are not visualized or the anatomy is not recognizable.

objective.__html: Evaluate for deep venous thrombosis using point-of-care ultrasonography.

children: A 31-year-old woman is evaluated for asymptomatic thrombocytopenia. She is 10 weeks pregnant.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

text.__html: HELLP (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) syndrome

children: The most likely diagnosis is pseudothrombocytopenia. Pseudothrombocytopenia is an artifact in which platelets agglutinate and the clumped platelets are not recognized by automated blood counters. In this situation, the large platelet clumps (
arrow
) may be
seen
on the stained blood film. These clumps occasionally adhere to neutrophils but may also be unassociated with any other cell types.

objective.__html: Diagnose pseudothrombocytopenia caused by platelet clumping.

children: A 46-year-old woman is evaluated for unexplained anemia.
A Prussian blue–stained bone marrow aspiration is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is sideroblastic anemia. This bone marrow examination is remarkable for the presence of
ringed sideroblasts

. These cells are characterized by small, blue-staining, iron-containing granules arranged in a ring around the nucleus of erythroid precursors. Ringed sideroblasts are associated with a variety of disorders that have ineffective erythropoiesis and hyperferremia in common. Sideroblastic anemia may be congenital or acquired. Acquired forms may be associated with the myelodysplastic syndrome; be idiopathic; or occur in the context of alcohol use disorder, copper deficiency, lead toxicity, or the use of certain drugs (such as linezolid and isoniazid).

objective.__html: Diagnose ringed sideroblasts and associated sideroblastic anemia.

children: A 65-year-old man is evaluated for pancytopenia.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is acute myeloid leukemia (AML). This peripheral blood smear
shows
an immature granulocyte with a rod-shaped inclusion body (Auer rod) (
arrow
) characteristic of AML. Auer rods represent linear collections of granules and are virtually diagnostic of AML.
A 48-year-old man is evaluated for the recent onset of a macular, nonblanching rash on his legs, ankles, and dorsal feet. He is otherwise asymptomatic.
The rash is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is thrombocytopenia, which is causing this patient's petechiae. A petechia is a round, discrete, hemorrhagic area typically less than 2 mm in diameter that, in this case, is caused by dermal hemorrhage resulting from thrombocytopenia. As the lesion ages and the hemoglobin is metabolized, the color changes from bright red to green to yellow and then fades. Petechiae do not blanch with pressure and are flat and nontender.

objective.__html: Diagnose petechiae and recognize their association with thrombocytopenia.

children: A 30-year-old woman develops fever and the skin rash
shown
following an erythrocyte transfusion of packed red blood cells, which had not undergone irradiation. She is receiving chemotherapy for Hodgkin disease.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). Transfusion-associated GVHD is a rare but usually fatal complication in which donor lymphocytes in a transfused cellular blood product (erythrocytes or platelets) engraft in an immunocompromised recipient and cause toxic effects in the bone marrow, skin, liver, and gastrointestinal tract. Patients at risk include those receiving chemotherapy for autoimmune disorders or malignancy, recipients of blood components from first-degree relatives, and premature infants. The first and most common clinical manifestation of acute GVHD is a maculopapular exanthem that can progress to bullae formation. The rash first appears at the nape of the neck and on the ears, shoulders, palms of the hands, and soles of the feet and may be pruritic or painful. To prevent this complication, blood given to immunocompromised patients should be irradiated.

A 33-year-old man with right lower extremity swelling is evaluated for possible deep venous thrombosis. Ultrasonography is performed with the probe just below the inguinal ligament in the transverse plane.
(Note that there is no sound for this
video
Which of the following is seen in this study?
The ultrasound video demonstrates abnormal compression (noncompressibility) of the common femoral vein
shown
in top image) consistent with deep venous thrombosis (DVT). Normally, the anterior and posterior walls of a vein (
blue arrows
) will touch with the application of gentle pressure with the probe (compressibility), whereas the artery (
red arrows in the still image, and pulsatile in the video image
) is minimally compressible with pressure. Normal compressibility of the vein is
shown
in the bottom image.

However, as shown in this study, a clot prevents normal compression of the vein, which is consistent with the presence of DVT. Compared with formal venous ultrasonography, which examines the entire lower extremity venous system, a point-of-care study for DVT typically images three sites: the common femoral vein; the junction of the common femoral, femoral, and deep femoral veins; and the popliteal vein at the level of the knee. Results of a point-of-care study for DVT should be considered indeterminate if the intended vessels are not visualized or the anatomy is not recognizable. In this case, the vein is shown paired with an artery, and the level of visualization may be determined by recognition of its junction with the greater saphenous vein on the right side of the video.

objective.__html: Evaluate for deep venous thrombosis using point-of-care ultrasonography.

children: A 57-year-old woman is evaluated for fever, hypotension, and respiratory distress at the end of an erythrocyte transfusion.
Chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). TRALI is defined as noncardiogenic pulmonary edema that occurs within 6 hours of transfusion. These patients are more likely to present with fever and hypotension and less likely to have overt signs of volume overload as in patients with transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). Radiographic findings usually suggest a noncardiac pulmonary edema or acute respiratory distress syndrome but may resemble those seen in TACO.
A 19-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for acute abdominal and back pain.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is sickle cell disease, which is characterized by numerous spindle- or crescent-shaped erythrocytes, also known as drepanocytes, as
shown
on the peripheral blood smear. Additional findings often include target cells and Howell-Jolly bodies (nuclear remnants usually removed by the spleen).
A 58-year-old man is evaluated for macrocytic anemia. He also has leukopenia and thrombocytopenia.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is myelodysplastic syndrome. The peripheral blood smear from this patient with myelodysplastic syndrome
shows
a dysplastic neutrophil (
white arrow
) with hypogranular cytoplasm and a dysplastic nucleus. A nucleated erythrocyte is also seen in this field (
black arrow
). The myelodysplastic syndromes are clonal stem cell disorders with ineffective hematopoiesis leading to dysplastic, hypercellular bone marrow and peripheral blood cytopenias.
A 53-year-old man is evaluated by a peripheral blood smear, as
shown
, after an abnormality was found on a routine complete blood count. He is asymptomatic.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is essential thrombocythemia. On the peripheral smear
shown
, platelets appear as small, purplish cells without a nucleus (
white arrow

). As a rule of thumb, there are normally about 8-15 platelets per 100-power field. The peripheral blood smear contains many more than this number of platelets, suggesting a very high platelet count and the possible diagnosis of essential thrombocythemia. Other clues to the diagnosis of essential thrombocythemia are the presence of large platelets (
yellow arrow

) and platelet fragments. Most patients with essential thrombocythemia are asymptomatic and present with an elevated platelet count found on routine laboratory testing. Patients may present with vasomotor symptoms, such as headache, visual disturbances, dysesthesia of the palms and soles, syncope, and livedo reticularis. Other complications of essential thrombocythemia include thrombosis and hemorrhage.
An 18-year-old woman is diagnosed with anemia.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is iron deficiency anemia. Red blood cells are normally the size of the nucleus of a small lymphocyte. In this smear, they are significantly smaller, indicating microcytosis. In addition to the microcytosis, this peripheral blood smear illustrates the other most common findings associated with iron deficiency anemia: hypochromia (increase in the central pallor of cells), poikilocytosis (changes in erythrocyte shape), and anisocytosis (changes in erythrocyte size).
A 26-year-old man is evaluated following an episode of acute hemolytic anemia.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. The peripheral blood smear is notable for the presence of bite cells at the center of the slide (
black arrow
Bite cells

are typical findings in G6PD deficiency and are characterized by a membrane defect that appears as though a semicircular bite has been taken out of the erythrocyte. The defect is caused by removal of denatured hemoglobin by macrophages in the spleen. A polychromatophilic macro-ovalocyte can also be seen (
blue arrow

), indicating a reticulocyte response. Hemolysis occurs in patients with G6PD deficiency when exposed to an oxidative stress, most commonly medications. The diagnosis is confirmed by a low G6PD level, although testing performed immediately after a hemolytic episode may be falsely negative, as many of the G6PD-deficient cells were hemolyzed. Repeat testing after recovery may be necessary.
A 59-year-old man is evaluated for anemia, acute kidney injury, and lytic bone lesions.
A bone marrow biopsy is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is multiple myeloma. This patient's bone marrow is packed with plasma cells that have findings typical for mature plasma cells. The cells are oval and nearly filled with basophilic cytoplasm. The nucleus is round and eccentric, and an area of cytoplasmic clearing (“perinuclear hof”) is
seen
near the nucleus (
arrow

objective.__html: Diagnose multiple myeloma on the basis of bone marrow findings.

children: A 21-year-old woman is evaluated for anemia. She is asymptomatic.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is thalassemia minor. The peripheral blood smear in thalassemia
shown
is characterized by target cells (
black arrow
) and teardrop cells (
blue arrow

). Thalassemias are congenital disorders characterized by imbalanced globin chain production or synthesis of abnormal globin chains. The resulting excess of cell membrane relative to cell volume results in microcytic target cells contributing to a microcytic, hypochromic anemia. Thalassemia minor is the most likely diagnosis for an asymptomatic patient with the peripheral blood smear shown in the top image. Although not an answer option, iron deficiency anemia may have a similar appearance on peripheral smear.
A 60-year-old man is evaluated for changes in his tongue. He also reports increased
bruising
and hepatomegaly.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is immunoglobulin light-chain amyloidosis. In primary (systemic) AL amyloidosis, amyloid deposits in multiple organs, including the tongue. The presence of macroglossia is highly suggestive of AL amyloidosis. Skin manifestations are present in 30% to 40% of patients and include generalized waxy appearance; easy bruising with minor pressure (pinch purpura); violaceous discoloration around the eyes (“raccoon eyes”); yellow waxy papules and plaques, especially in a periorbital location; and dystrophic nails.

objective.__html: Diagnose macroglossia associated with AL amyloidosis.

children: A 51-year-old woman is evaluated for fatigue, weight loss, fever, chills, and splenomegaly.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is myelofibrosis. This patient's leukoerythroblastic blood smear
shows
left-shifted granulopoiesis (bands on either side of a large myelocyte above a metamyelocyte in
brackets
) and nucleated (
blue arrow
) and teardrop-shaped (
green arrow

) erythrocytes, which define a crowded myelophthisic marrow. This pattern is seen in primary myelofibrosis or other secondary infiltrative processes of the marrow, such as metastatic carcinoma. A mature neutrophil is seen in the bottom right of the image.

Primary myelofibrosis is a clonal myeloid stem cell disorder with characteristic marrow fibrosis and extramedullary hematopoiesis. This increased fibrosis is thought to be related to proliferation of clonal megakaryocytes, which secrete excess fibroblast growth factor. Hematopoietic progenitors are increased in the circulation, providing a leukoerythroblastic picture seen on the peripheral blood smear shown.
A 58-year-old man is evaluated for fatigue, pallor, and changes in his nails, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is iron deficiency anemia. Koilonychia (spoon nails) is a finding associated with iron deficiency anemia and other microcytic anemias. The natural nail convexity is replaced by concave nails. This finding is now rarely seen because of the widespread use of automated blood counts that identify most patients with anemia before it becomes chronic and severe. This condition has also been associated with rheumatic fever, lichen planus, and syphilis.

objective.__html: Identify koilonychia and its association with iron deficiency anemia.

children: A 50-year-old man is evaluated for the nephrotic syndrome, elevated aminotransferase levels, peripheral neuropathy, and easy bruising.
The periorbital area of the patient's face is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is AL amyloidosis. Periorbital purpura ("raccoon eyes" or pinch purpura) is not very sensitive but is highly specific for AL amyloidosis. This finding is often elicited by a Valsalva maneuver or minor trauma. AL amyloidosis is the most common type of amyloidosis. It is a clonal plasma cell dyscrasia characterized by production of amyloidogenic λ or κ free light chains. These light chains can deposit in various organs, resulting in varying clinical presentations of the disease.

objective.__html: Diagnose pinch purpura and its association with AL amyloidosis.

children: A 50-year-old woman is evaluated in the ICU for painful changes in her fingers, as
shown
, following placement of a right radial artery catheter 5 days ago. She has been receiving heparin therapy since admission. Her platelet count was normal on admission but it is now 35,000/μL (35 × 10
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is heparin-induced thrombocytopenia and thrombosis (HITT). Up to 2% of patients treated with heparin develop heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, and approximately 30% of such patients develop HITT. In patients with HITT, venous thrombi occur two- to fourfold more often than do arterial thrombi, although in patients with underlying arterial disease this ratio is reversed. Thrombi have a propensity to form in areas of vascular damage, such as in vessels in which indwelling catheters have been placed, as in this patient.
A 40-year-old man is evaluated for weakness and easy fatigability, gingival bleeding, ecchymoses, and epistaxis.
Bone marrow aspirate is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is acute promyelocytic leukemia, which is characterized by poorly differentiated leukocytes with distinctive primary granules that contribute to coagulopathy. This patient's bone marrow aspirate is consistent with acute promyelocytic leukemia showing the presence of many violet
granules
black
a
rrow
) in the cytoplasm and a high nucleus to cytoplasmic ratio. Folded nuclei and clusters of Auer rods (
red arrow
) are also noted. Granulation of the promyelocytes may be subtle, giving the cells a “dusky” appearance.
A 69-year-old man is evaluated for anemia and arm pain.
A radiograph of the right humerus is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely cause of the radiographic findings is multiple myeloma. This image shows punched-out lytic lesions of the humerus. Lytic lesions are found in nearly 60% of patients with multiple myeloma and most frequently involve the vertebral bodies, skull, thoracic cage, pelvis, and proximal humeral and femoral bones. Bone lesions in metastatic prostate cancer and Paget disease tend to have significant osteoblastic changes, whereas osteomyelitis is marked by periosteal reaction and bone destruction.

objective.__html: Diagnose lytic lesions of multiple myeloma.

children: A 66-year-old woman is evaluated for anemia.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This peripheral blood smear is compatible with megaloblastic anemia. A hypersegmented neutrophil (more than five distinct lobes) is present and supports the diagnosis of megaloblastic anemia. Other findings consistent with megaloblastic anemia include oval-shaped enlarged erythrocytes (macro-ovalocytes). Pancytopenia resulting from ineffective hematopoiesis can also be seen. Causes include folate and/or cobalamin deficiencies and drugs affecting folate metabolism and/or DNA synthesis. Because megaloblastic causes of anemia affect trilineage hematopoiesis, leukopenia and thrombocytopenia may accompany anemia.

objective.__html: Diagnose megaloblastic anemia on a peripheral blood smear.

children: A 40-year-old woman is evaluated for an episode of dyspnea and syncope.
CT angiogram is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
This contrast-enhanced CT angiogram
shows
multiple intraluminal filling defects (
white arrows
), consistent with a diagnosis of pulmonary thromboembolism.

objective.__html: Diagnose pulmonary embolism on a CT angiogram.

children: A 33-year-old woman is evaluated for the sudden appearance of a rapidly expanding painful skin lesion on her leg. She had a miscarriage 1 year ago. Her activated partial thromboplastin time is prolonged.
The skin lesion is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APAS), an autoimmune disorder in which thrombosis and fetal demise (in pregnancy) may occur. This patient's large area of jaggedly branching, angulated retiform purpura is a manifestation of intravascular clot formation in the small vessels of the skin, leading to overlying skin necrosis. Angulated retiform purpura can be the presenting manifestation of APAS.

Diagnosis of APAS is based on the clinical criteria of thromboembolism or pregnancy morbidity and laboratory findings of medium- or high-titer antiphospholipid antibodies (anticardiolipin antibodies and lupus anticoagulant) present on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart. A clue to the presence of lupus anticoagulant is prolongation of activated partial thromboplastin time, as seen with this patient.
A 20-year-old man is evaluated for fever, malaise, and gingival bleeding.
Peripheral blood smear is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). In ALL, the leukocyte count can be low, normal, or elevated, but most patients have circulating lymphoblasts as seen in this smear. Lymphoblasts vary from small cells with minimal cytoplasm, condensed nuclear chromatin, and difficult to visualize nucleoli to larger cells with moderate amounts of cytoplasm, dispersed chromatin, and multiple nucleoli. Auer rods are never present. ALL is more common in children and adolescents than in adults. Patients with ALL present with malaise, bleeding, infections, bone pain, or a combination of these symptoms, with a small subset (<10%) having symptomatic central nervous system involvement at diagnosis. Although the smear suggests the diagnosis, flow cytometry is needed to confirm the presence of ALL.
